pages.name: Tech that has changed my life

content.html:
Writing melodies

I've been obsessed with writing melodies for a long time. I have hundreds upon hundreds saved on Voice Memos on my phone, and many more I haven't recorded but remember and sing when the trigger phrase comes up. Usually if I say it more than three times (often to my wife), I'll turn it into a melody: "we're going to be late", "that's too expensive", etc. I have particular melodies for members of my family, family pets, and things that they do and say. They're catchy, I think, but they won't win any awards or be turned into hit songs, although I guess if you were writing music for children you could use some of them.

But what I really love about it is that it's an exercise in listening to the part of my brain that acts on instinct. This is something I've struggled with for a long time, considering that I usually overthink things. For a long time I thought that the best way to do things was to read books about it, figure it out from every angle, then do it, but always with an eye on the reference manuals. Writing melodies reminds me that creating, and doing, are processes we most often can't control. Most of the things we do are much more like rolling a ball down a hill than flying a plane. Planes have lots of controls and require constant monitoring and correcting (as far as I know, I'm not a pilot), but rolling a ball down a hill and trying to hit a target is something you have a very limited amount of control over. You start at the top, you roll it, you see what went wrong and adjust, and then you roll it again.

There's a famous book on this subject called "Thinking, Fast and Slow." I wasn't able to get more than a few chapters through it because it's too long, and I think the gist of it doesn't really need 32 chapters to explain anyway, but the basic idea is that you have two brains: one thinks fast, the other thinks slow. Most of our decisions are done with the fast brain, but it's the responsibility of the slow brain to train the fast brain.

When you write a melody, you're entirely using your fast brain. Songwriters often say that they feel like they're getting the melody from somewhere else, because that's what it feels like to write a melody. It's creation that happens naturally, and like so many things is almost more experienced than practiced.
content.markdown:
# Writing melodies

I've been obsessed with writing melodies for a long time. I have hundreds upon hundreds saved on Voice Memos on my phone, and many more I haven't recorded but remember and sing when the trigger phrase comes up. Usually if I say it more than three times (often to my wife), I'll turn it into a melody: "we're going to be late", "that's too expensive", etc. I have particular melodies for members of my family, family pets, and things that they do and say. They're catchy, I think, but they won't win any awards or be turned into hit songs, although I guess if you were writing music for children you could use some of them.

But what I really love about it is that it's an exercise in listening to the part of my brain that acts on instinct. This is something I've struggled with for a long time, considering that I usually overthink things. For a long time I thought that the best way to do things was to read books about it, figure it out from every angle, then do it, but always with an eye on the reference manuals. Writing melodies reminds me that creating, and doing, are processes we most often can't control. Most of the things we do are much more like rolling a ball down a hill than flying a plane. Planes have lots of controls and require constant monitoring and correcting (as far as I know, I'm not a pilot), but rolling a ball down a hill and trying to hit a target is something you have a very limited amount of control over. You start at the top, you roll it, you see what went wrong and adjust, and then you roll it again.

There's a famous book on this subject called "Thinking, Fast and Slow." I wasn't able to get more than a few chapters through it because it's too long, and I think the gist of it doesn't really need 32 chapters to explain anyway, but the basic idea is that you have two brains: one thinks fast, the other thinks slow. Most of our decisions are done with the fast brain, but it's the responsibility of the slow brain to train the fast brain.

When you write a melody, you're entirely using your fast brain. Songwriters often say that they feel like they're getting the melody from somewhere else, because that's what it feels like to write a melody. It's creation that happens naturally, and like so many things is almost more experienced than practiced.

content.html:
Svelte

I started my real professional career building fancy websites for big universities. Not the kinds of designs that JS devs are used to (usually thrown together to get data from one place to another), but designs that are a part of the end product and value designy-presentation over functional-presentation. In that world, pixels matter, and approximations are rejected. More than that, it means that all of my time would be spent working with HTML and CSS, and when JS was introduced it would be to add specific interactivity.

So when I started learning React, it was an upheaval of what I was used to, and more than that it introduced an incredible amount of complexity that I now had to learn, which took away time from building the thing I was supposed to be building. Given the option of building a web application with React vs HTML & CSS, the answer if of course clear - considering you can't really build an application with just HTML and CSS. But once that road has been started on, additional technologies build on it, and suddenly we find ourselves building normal websites with React. Sites that don't have any interactivity at all are being built with this heavy JavaScript framework that was never intended for this type of product. The image that always comes to mind is of someone using a crane to build a house; it would be reasonably effective, sure, but it's not the tool you would come up with if you were designing a tool for the job.

I say this as someone who has used React professionally, and was heading down the path of being a professional "React developer", happily eyeballing the increasingly high salaries that were waiting for me. I felt powerful learning Redux, not because I understood it or could be more effective with it, but because I could picture it on my resume. I could imagine myself suggesting we use Redux in our next dev meeting and become the "Redux guy". Again, I didn't really understand why it was necessary, or what problem it solved, but I knew that it was the hot thing everyone was talking about and I wanted to be a part of it.

I don't have the authority or experience to say Redux is valuable or not - I'm sure it is - but I do have the authority to say what it was that drew me to it. It's a similar feeling to what drew me to cryptocurrency - money, status. I didn't understand it, or know how it was useful, but its promise of success so enticed me that I gave up my valuable resources to bet on it.

An aside on cryptcurrency: Cryptocurrency has taken the world by storm, billions or trillions of dollars have been invested in it. There have been those who have made fortunes, and there have been those who have lost fortunes, but what there hasn't been is more value added. Cryptocurrency is a zero-sum game, where a dollar gained is a dollar lost. It's completely misunderstood by almost everyone who uses it, but a person doesn't have to understand it to participate anymore than an 80-something sitting at a slot machine has to understand what happens when they pull the lever. If the only reason cryptocurrency was invested in or marketed was because it was creating market value, it would be an esoteric technology at best. The fact that is isn't is a testament to the real reason it's famous: because it made a lot of people a lot of money.

This was supposed to be an article touting the technical values of Svelte, but instead I can't help but write about how it showed me what to bet on in life.
content.markdown:
# Svelte

I started my *real *professional career building fancy websites for big universities. Not the kinds of designs that JS devs are used to (usually thrown together to get data from one place to another), but designs that are a part of the end product and value designy-presentation over functional-presentation. In that world, pixels matter, and approximations are rejected. More than that, it means that all of my time would be spent working with HTML and CSS, and when JS was introduced it would be to add specific interactivity.

So when I started learning React, it was an upheaval of what I was used to, and more than that it introduced an incredible amount of complexity that I now had to learn, which took away time from building the thing I was supposed to be building. Given the option of building a web application with React vs HTML & CSS, the answer if of course clear - considering you can't really build an application with just HTML and CSS. But once that road has been started on, additional technologies build on it, and suddenly we find ourselves building *normal *websites with React. Sites that don't have any interactivity at all are being built with this heavy JavaScript framework that was never intended for this type of product. The image that always comes to mind is of someone using a crane to build a house; it would be reasonably effective, sure, but it's not the tool you would come up with if you were designing a tool for the job.

I say this as someone who has used React professionally, and was heading down the path of being a professional "React developer", happily eyeballing the increasingly high salaries that were waiting for me. I felt powerful learning Redux, not because I understood it or could be more effective with it, but because I could picture it on my resume. I could imagine myself suggesting we use Redux in our next dev meeting and become the "Redux guy". Again, I didn't really understand why it was necessary, or what problem it solved, but I knew that it was the hot thing everyone was talking about and I wanted to be a part of it.

I don't have the authority or experience to say Redux is valuable or not - I'm sure it is - but I do have the authority to say what it was that drew me to it. It's a similar feeling to what drew me to cryptocurrency - money, status. I didn't understand it, or know how it was useful, but its promise of success so enticed me that I gave up my valuable resources to bet on it.

An aside on cryptcurrency: Cryptocurrency has taken the world by storm, billions or trillions of dollars have been invested in it. There have been those who have made fortunes, and there have been those who have lost fortunes, but what there hasn't been is more value added. Cryptocurrency is a zero-sum game, where a dollar gained is a dollar lost. It's completely misunderstood by almost everyone who uses it, but a person doesn't have to understand it to participate anymore than an 80-something sitting at a slot machine has to understand what happens when they pull the lever. If the only reason cryptocurrency was invested in or marketed was because it was creating market value, it would be an esoteric technology at best. The fact that is isn't is a testament to the real reason it's famous: because it made a lot of people a lot of money.

This was supposed to be an article touting the technical values of Svelte, but instead I can't help but write about how it showed me what to bet on in life.

en.name: Mateo Morris
en.title: Frontend Developer

description.html: Primo is a visual CMS that includes an embedded development environment and deploys a static site. It combined the ideas of component-driven development, static sites, and more.
description.markdown: Primo is a visual CMS that includes an embedded development environment and deploys a static site. It combined the ideas of component-driven development, static sites, and more.

description.html: Contributed professionally to the Expensify mobile app codebase.
description.markdown: Contributed professionally to the Expensify mobile app codebase.

description.html: Made a large contribution to the Supabase authentication codebase by enabling login with Github to enable Github account permissions.
description.markdown: Made a large contribution to the Supabase authentication codebase by enabling login with Github to enable Github account permissions.

en.introduction: I'm a Frontend Developer with 10 years of varied development experience as a freelancer, educator, agency developer, and open-source founder. My obsession is in finding more efficient ways to do things & opening up the web for others.

description.html: I’m a frontend developer/educator working on WeaveCMS - a tool that makes web development more approachable by leveraging component-driven development & Svelte.
description.markdown: I’m a frontend developer/educator working on [WeaveCMS](<https://weavecms.com>) \- a tool that makes web development more approachable by leveraging component-driven development & [Svelte](<https://svelte.dev>).

description.html: Built the frontend as components in Fractal that they put together into the main site and other departments' websites on subdomains. Seeing them take those base components and build out other sites was a large inspiration for thinking about how components work in Primo.
description.markdown: Built the frontend as components in Fractal that they put together into the main site and other departments' websites on subdomains. Seeing them take those base components and build out other sites was a large inspiration for thinking about how components work in Primo.

description.html: Created official mobile app for iOS and Android using React Native & a WordPress instance as a headless CMS.
description.markdown: Created official mobile app for iOS and Android using React Native & a WordPress instance as a headless CMS.

description.html: Collaborated on frontend and handed off for integration with WordPress.
description.markdown: Collaborated on frontend and handed off for integration with WordPress.

items.title: University of Tennessee: Architecture and Design

description.html: Collaborated on frontend to be handed off for integration with WordPress.
description.markdown: Collaborated on frontend to be handed off for integration with WordPress.

description.html: Microsite for local university's anniversary, built and integrated into WordPress.
description.markdown: Microsite for local university's anniversary, built and integrated into WordPress.

items.title: Pomona College: Benton Museum of Art

description.html: I built a custom page containing an interactive component that displayed posts from Instagram. I built it in React (this was before Svelte); it wasn't too bad, but getting my code updates onto the website was always painful.
description.markdown: I built a custom page containing an interactive component that displayed posts from Instagram. I built it in React (this was before Svelte); it wasn't too bad, but getting my code updates onto the website was always painful.

description.html: One of the first projects I was a part of at NewCity. I shadowed a senior developer and learned how to build components stored in a Fractal component library using the Twig templating language & SCSS.
description.markdown: One of the first projects I was a part of at NewCity. I shadowed a senior developer and learned how to build components stored in a Fractal component library using the Twig templating language & SCSS.

description.html: Weave is an intermediary tool - an approachable (any device, any technical background), enjoyable, and productive open-source tool for creating common websites like blogs, landing pages, brochures, etc. My hope is that it opens up the door for more people to start coding and publish their first live website within minutes without code, the command line, or documentation, creating a gradual learning curve towards modifying code and building full-stack applications.
description.markdown: Weave is an intermediary tool - an approachable (any device, any technical background), enjoyable, and productive open-source tool for creating common websites like blogs, landing pages, brochures, etc. My hope is that it opens up the door for more people to start coding and publish their first live website within minutes without code, the command line, or documentation, creating a gradual learning curve towards modifying code and building full-stack applications.

description.html: My first Svelte project - an app that allowed my students to quietly tell me if I was belaboring on a topic (bored), or if I was going too fast (confused), as well as ask questions.
description.markdown: My first Svelte project - an app that allowed my students to quietly tell me if I was belaboring on a topic (bored), or if I was going too fast (confused), as well as ask questions.

description.html: The podcast app I always wanted to exist - with shows split up into subgroups (called "stations") that would shuffle all the latest episodes from each. Built in React Native, but abandoned when I started teaching (and frankly because React Native is pain and there were 2^42 podcast apps by then).
description.markdown: The podcast app I always wanted to exist - with shows split up into subgroups (called "stations") that would shuffle all the latest episodes from each. Built in React Native, but abandoned when I started teaching (and frankly because React Native is pain and there were 2^<sup>42</sup> podcast apps by then).

description.html: A chrome extension that mined crypto with unused GPU and donated the money to clean water projects. Unfortunately, the weirdness of using it didn't outweigh the penny it generated per hour.
description.markdown: A chrome extension that mined crypto with unused GPU and donated the money to clean water projects. Unfortunately, the weirdness of using it didn't outweigh the penny it generated per hour.

content.html:
Intro

I spent the first two years of my career poking around WordPress theme dashboards trying to get my website to do simple things, when what I really needed was to get to the code.

Unfortunately, things have only gone further since then with the growth of the no-code movement, which makes building websites easier in the short-term, but at the expense of cookie-cutter sites, expensive fees, and most importantly - the inability to access the platform.

HTML, CSS, and JavaScript are incredible tools for expression. They let anyone with a basic text editor and accessible education put anything on any screen in the world, without the permission of a middleman, and without the fear that it could be taken away or sold to the highest bidder.

Modern frontend development doesn't help much in this regard either. Countless students are churned through coding bootcamps every year, spending only a few weeks on these fundamental languages before learning the libraries and tools which seem to appeal to hiring managers. And as a result, many developers only learn how to do things with specialized tools without understanding the basics enough to know how to use them.

That's why tools which make empower web developers should not only build on those fundamentals, but make them as approachable as possible. Svelte is a prime example of this - it literally builds on the fundamental languages of the web in that all valid HTML, CSS, and JavaScript is valid Svelte. It picks up where the web languages left off to enable component-driven development, reactivity, style encapsulation, and more, and its meta-framework SvelteKit enables more people to build powerful full-stack web applications. Combined with feature-rich open-source backends like Supabase, modern developers are more capable than ever of building interactive, accessible, instantly and globally-available software.

But there's still a gap when it comes to content websites, the kinds of websites that most people need. This area is filled with a host of cookie-cutter monthly services which effectively rent out websites, or WordPress. WordPress is great, but only because Drupal's a pain. WordPress' developer experience, server-reliance, and security vulnerabilities are probably far outweighed by its benefits for most of the organizations using it, but for many of them (and many more who just can't use it) they're prohibitive.

Primo is our attempt to build an intermediary tool - a fully approachable (any device, any technical background), enjoyable, and productive open-source tool for building and publishing common websites like blogs, landing pages, brochures, etc. Our hope is that it opens up the door for more people to start coding and publish their first live website within minutes without code, the command line, or documentation, creating a gradual learning curve towards modifying code and building full-stack applications.
content.markdown:
## Intro

I spent the first two years of my career poking around WordPress theme dashboards trying to get my website to do simple things, when what I really needed was to get to the code.

Unfortunately, things have only gone further since then with the growth of the *no-code *movement, which makes building websites easier in the short-term, but at the expense of cookie-cutter sites, expensive fees, and most importantly - the inability to access the platform.

HTML, CSS, and JavaScript are incredible tools for expression. They let anyone with a basic text editor and accessible education put anything on any screen in the world, without the permission of a middleman, and without the fear that it could be taken away or sold to the highest bidder.

Modern frontend development doesn't help much in this regard either. Countless students are churned through coding bootcamps every year, spending only a few weeks on these fundamental languages before learning the libraries and tools which seem to appeal to hiring managers. And as a result, many developers only learn how to do things with specialized tools without understanding the basics enough to know how to use them.

That's why tools which make empower web developers should not only build on those fundamentals, but make them as approachable as possible. [**Svelte**](<https://kit.svelte.dev>) is a prime example of this - it literally builds on the fundamental languages of the web in that all valid HTML, CSS, and JavaScript is valid Svelte. It picks up where the web languages left off to enable component-driven development, reactivity, style encapsulation, and more, and its meta-framework [**SvelteKit**](<https://kit.svelte.dev>) enables more people to build powerful full-stack web applications. Combined with feature-rich open-source backends like Supabase, modern developers are more capable than ever of building interactive, accessible, instantly and globally-available software.

But there's still a gap when it comes to content websites, the kinds of websites that most people need. This area is filled with a host of cookie-cutter monthly services which effectively rent out websites, or WordPress. WordPress is great, but only because Drupal's a pain. WordPress' developer experience, server-reliance, and security vulnerabilities are probably far outweighed by its benefits for most of the organizations using it, but for many of them (and many more who just can't use it) they're prohibitive.

[**Primo**](<https://primo.so>) is our attempt to build an intermediary tool - a *fully* approachable (any device, any technical background), enjoyable, and productive open-source tool for building and publishing common websites like blogs, landing pages, brochures, etc. Our hope is that it opens up the door for more people to start coding and publish their first live website within minutes without code, the command line, or documentation, creating a gradual learning curve towards modifying code and building full-stack applications.

description.html: The precursor to Primo which started as a way to put up a curriculum page for my code bootcamp students at a custom domain without having to pay for hosting. I was close to monetizing it as a cheaper/simpler site builder, but seeing its potential as a dev tool encouraged me to expand its scope into Primo.
description.markdown: The precursor to Primo which started as a way to put up a curriculum page for my code bootcamp students at a custom domain without having to pay for hosting. I was close to monetizing it as a cheaper/simpler site builder, but seeing its potential as a dev tool encouraged me to expand its scope into Primo.

description.html: My first Svelte project - an app that allowed my students to quietly tell me if I had belabored too much on a topic (bored), or if I was going too fast (confused), as well as ask questions. It was working well, but then COVID hit.
description.markdown: My first Svelte project - an app that allowed my students to quietly tell me if I had belabored too much on a topic (bored), or if I was going too fast (confused), as well as ask questions. It was working well, but then COVID hit.

description.html: The podcast app I always wanted to exist - with shows split up into subgroups (called "stations") that would shuffle all the latest episodes from each. Built in React Native, but abandoned when I started teaching (and frankly because React Native is pain and there were 2^42 podcast apps by then).
